paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: The paper discusses the KCNH2 T618I mutation associated with Short QT Syndrome, detailing its functional effects, clinical significance, and penetrance data.

patients.phenotype: Short QT syndrome with family history of sudden cardiac death

individual_records.phenotype_details: Short QT syndrome with episodes of syncope
individual_records.evidence_sentence: The ECG screening showed a strong family history of SCD, and characteristics of SQTS including abbreviated QT intervals and peaked T-waves were also observed on the ECG.

functional_data.summary: The T618I mutation leads to a gain-of-function effect, increasing IKr and altering action potential dynamics.

variants.segregation_data: The T618I mutation segregates with disease in the family.
variants.evidence_level: Strong evidence based on functional assays and clinical correlation.
variants.additional_notes: The study emphasizes the arrhythmogenic potential of the T618I mutation and its implications for treatment.
key_quotes: The IKr was markedly increased in the T618I mutant channel, which was mainly caused by the significantly altered inactivation curve that shifted almost 50 mV towards the depolarized direction.

extraction_metadata.notes: All relevant data regarding the KCNH2 T618I mutation was successfully extracted.
